column1: Iowa City was the second capital of the Iowa Territory and the first capital city of the State of Iowa. The Old Capitol building is a National Historic Landmark in the center of the University of Iowa campus. The University of Iowa Art Museum and Plum Grove
column2: the home of the first Governor of Iowa
column3: are also tourist attractions. In 2008
column4: Forbes magazine named Iowa City the second-best small metropolitan area for doing business in the United States.

column1: Iowa City was created by an act of Legislative Assembly of the Iowa Territory on January 21
column3: fulfilling the desire of Governor Robert Lucas to move the capital out of Burlington and closer to the center of the territory. This act began:

column1: An Act to locate the Seat of Government of the Territory of Iowa ... so soon as the place shall be selected
column2: and the consent of the United States obtained
column3: the commissioners shall proceed to lay out a town to be called "Iowa City".

column1: Commissioners Chauncey Swan and John Ronalds met on May 1 in the small settlement of Napoleon
column2: south of present-day Iowa City
column3: to select a site for the new capital city. The following day the commissioners selected a site on bluffs above the Iowa River north of Napoleon
column4: placed a stake in the center of the proposed site and began planning the new capital city. Commissioner Swan
column5: in a report to the legislature in Burlington
column6: described the site:

column1: Iowa City is located on a section of land laying in the form of an amphitheater. There is an eminence on the west near the river
column2: running parallel with it."
the town had been platted and surveyed from Brown St. in the north to Burlington St. in the south
column3: and from the Iowa River eastward to Governor St.

column1: While Iowa City was selected as the territorial capital in 1839
column2: it did not officially become the capital city until 1841; after construction on the capitol building had begun. The capitol building was completed in 1842
column3: and the last four territorial legislatures and the first six Iowa General Assemblies met there until 1857
column4: when the state capital was moved to Des Moines.

column1: John F. Rague is credited with designing the Territorial Capitol Building. He had previously designed the 1837 capitol of Illinois and was supervising its construction when he got the commission to design the new Iowa capitol in 1839. He quit the Iowa project after five months
column2: claiming his design was not followed
column3: but the resemblance to the Illinois capitol suggests he strongly influenced the final Iowa design. One surviving 1839 sketch of the proposed capital shows a radically different layout
column4: with two domes and a central tower. The cornerstone of the Old Capitol Building was laid in Iowa City on July 4
column5: 1840. Iowa City served as the third and last territorial capital of Iowa
column6: and the last four territorial legislatures met at the Old Capitol Building until December 28
column8: when Iowa was admitted into the United States as the 29th state of the union. Iowa City was declared the state capital of Iowa
column9: and the government convened in the Old Capitol Building.

column1: Oakland Cemetery was deeded to "the people of Iowa City" by the Iowa territorial legislature on February 13
column2: 1843. The original plot was one block square
column3: with the southwest corner at Governor and Church. Over the years the cemetery has been expanded and now encompasses 40 acres. Oakland Cemetery is a non-perpetual care city cemetery. This cemetery is supported by city taxes. The staff is strongly committed to the maintenance and preservation of privately owned lots and accessories. Since its establishment

column7: governor during the Civil War (1860–64)

column11: Walter A. Jessup (1915–33) and Virgil M. Hancher (1940–64); Cordelia Swan
column12: daughter of one of the three commissioners who selected the site for Iowa City and the new territorial capitol; and Irving B. Weber (1900–1997)

column1: The spring of 1970 was a tumultuous time on college campuses. On April 30
column2: President Richard Nixon announced that U.S. forces would invade Cambodia because of the recent communist coup. Students around the country protested this escalation of the Vietnam War. On May 4
column3: the National Guard fired on students at Kent State University
column4: killing four and wounding nine people
column5: which ignited protests all over the country.Anti-war protests were not new to Iowa City or to elsewhere in Iowa; protests had been occurring throughout the 1960s. Spring of 1970 was different.After the Kent State shootings
column6: students marched on the National Guard Armory
column7: broke windows there as well as in some downtown businesses. The City Council gave the mayor curfew powers. On May 6
column8: there was a student boycott of classes. That night
column9: about 400 people had a "sleep-in" in front of the Old Capitol.  That night also
column10: about 50 people broke into the Old Capitol and set off a smoke bomb. The protesters left voluntarily when asked to do so. Around 2 am Friday morning

column12: but the next day he regretted the mass arrests and said he had received faulty information. On May 8
column13: President Boyd cancelled the 89th annual Governor's day ROTC observance for the following day. On Friday and Saturday a National Guard helicopter circled the Pentacrest.In the early morning hours of Saturday

column1: Students should not accept everything that is dished out to them. We don't want to dictate what they should or should not do. However, student demonstrations should remain within the law and good taste without interfering with the university's primary purpose of instructing students.During this time

a confirmed EF2 tornado struck Iowa City
column4: causing severe property damage and displacing many from their homes

column1: A local newspaper reported on June 11
column3: that water exceeded the emergency spillway at the Coralville Reservoir outside of Iowa City. As a result
column4: the City of Iowa City and the University of Iowa were seriously affected by unprecedented flooding of the Iowa River
column5: which caused widespread property damage and forced evacuations in large sections of the city. By Friday June 13
column7: the Iowa River had risen to a record level of 30.46 feet (9.28 m) (5:00 pm CST) with a crest of approximately 33 feet (10 m) predicted for Wednesday June 18
column8: 2008. Much of the city's 500-year floodplain saw mild to catastrophic effects of the rapidly flowing
column9: polluted water. Officials at the University of Iowa reported that up to 19 buildings were affected by rising waters. Extensive efforts to move materials from the University's main library were undertaken as large groups of sandbagging volunteers began to construct a massive levee near the building. Approximately $300 million worth of art
column11: owned by the University was secretly moved to a holding place in the Chicago area before the fine arts area was heavily hit with flood water.

column2: June 13
column3: university employees were encouraged to stay home
column4: and travel was strongly discouraged in Iowa City; one city statement advised
column5: "If you live in east Iowa City
column6: stay in east Iowa City; if you live in west Iowa City
column7: stay in west Iowa City." The Burlington St. bridge was the only bridge that remained open
column8: other than the I-80 bridge on the edge of town
column9: to connect the east and west sides of the Iowa River. On Saturday
column11: officials at the University of Iowa began to power down the University's primary power generating plant along the Iowa River to prevent structural damage. Backup units continued to provide necessary power and steam services for essential University services
column12: including the University of Iowa Hospitals and Clinics. Water began touching the bottom of the Park St. bridge forcing the Army Corps of Engineers to drill several holes in the bridge to allow air trapped underneath to escape. Also on Saturday
column13: Mayor Regenia Bailey issued a curfew restricting anyone except those authorized by law enforcement from being within 100 yards (91 m) of any area affected by the flood between 8:30 pm and 6 am.

column2: a University of Iowa construction site was effectively damming the river just north of the bridge at Iowa Avenue and south of the train bridge crossing the river adjacent to the Iowa Memorial Union. The site had been erected ten months prior
column3: presumably to work on the University of Iowa steam power and thermal control system. It is unknown whether the Army Corps of Engineers were persuaded by University officials to maintain water levels below 26 feet (7.9 m) to maintain the work site in the three weeks preceding the major flood event
column4: or if Army Corps of Engineers made the decision to preserve the site on their own. Iowa City's riverside residents were aware of this
column5: particularly those living along Normandy Drive adjacent to City Park. A cofferdam structure may have impeded flow of the river
column6: and the Army Corps of Engineers' decision to forgo the discharge of additional multi-thousands of cubic feet of water in weeks prior has been criticized by many
column7: and displaced residents even attempted to bring a class action lawsuit against the Army Corps of Engineers and the University of Iowa.

column1: Iowa City has a humid continental climate
column2: hot summer subtype (Dfa in the Köppen climate classification). Average monthly temperatures range from about 23.5 °F (−4.7 °C). in January to 75.5 °F (24.2 °C). in July. Average monthly precipitation is lowest in winter and peaks significantly from May to August
column3: with June being the average wettest month. Showers and thunderstorms are common from May to September
column4: and can be severe
column5: especially from May to July. In winter
column6: snowfall is moderate
column7: occasionally heavy in single storms. Snow cover is occasional in drier and/or warmer winter seasons
column8: but (rarely) can be continuous in the coldest seasons
column9: such as that of 1978–79. The Iowa City area was struck by a severe hailstorm on May 18
column13: Iowa City's tornado risk is lower than in areas to the south and southwest

Ned Ashton House, built as a private residence by Iowa bridge engineer Ned Ashton in 1947, was placed on the National Register of Historic Places in 2001. Today, it is a popular venue that can accommodate up to 100 people for meetings, reunions, parties, weddings and receptions along the banks of the Iowa River.


=== Historic places on the National Register ===

		
		
		
		
		
		
		
		
		
		
		


=== Pedestrian Mall ===

City Plaza (commonly called the Pedestrian Mall or simply Ped Mall) serves as a gathering place for students and locals and draws large crowds for its summertime events such as the Friday Night Concert Series and the annual Iowa City Jazz Festival and Iowa City Arts Festival. The Ped Mall area contains restaurants, bars, retail, hotels, and the Iowa City Public Library.  It is known for its appeal to various local artists and musicians, and its wild bar scene. The Coldren Opera House was located on the street which has now become the mall.


== Education ==
The Iowa City Community School District operates public schools in Iowa City. Iowa City High School, Iowa City West High School, Liberty High School are the three public high schools. Iowa City is home to The University of Iowa and a branch of Kirkwood Community College.
The Iowa City Japanese School (アイオワシティ補習授業校 Aiowa Shiti Hoshū Jugyō Kō), a weekend educational program for Japanese nationals, provides Japanese language instruction, holding its classes at Zion Lutheran Church.


== Sports ==

Iowa City is home of the University of Iowa's athletic teams, known as the Iowa Hawkeyes. A member of the Big Ten Conference, the football team plays at Kinnick Stadium, while men's and women's basketball, volleyball, and the wrestling and gymnastics teams compete at Carver-Hawkeye Arena. The Hawkeyes football team regularly sends players to the NFL, including Super Bowl Champion all-pro Baltimore Ravens guard Marshall Yanda, 2004 2nd overall draft pick Robert Gallery, and San Francisco 49ers tight end George Kittle, among many others. Kirk Ferentz is the longest tenured head coach in NCAA FBS dating back to the 1999–2000 season.
Iowa City's two public high schools, City and West, are members of the Mississippi Valley Conference.
The Iowa City Gold Sox were a semi-professional baseball team that called Iowa City home from 1912 through 1913.


== Parks and recreation ==
Hickory Hill Park is a large wooded park on the north side of town.
City Park is located across the river from north Dubuque Street, and contains walking paths, baseball diamonds, tennis courts and an outdoor pool complex.
Hubbard Park is directly adjacent to the south side of the Iowa Memorial Union building and is a large green space used by many students for team activities and events.
Thornberry Dog Park is on the east side of the river in-between two bends in the river referred to by developers as the peninsula" upstream of City Park. This area is also home to a small Frisbee golf park which is often flooded.

column1: Iowa City is governed by an elected city council of seven members: four council members at large and three district members. The two council members at large who receive the most votes and the three district council members serve four-year terms. The other two council members at large serve two-year terms. A mayor and mayor pro tem are elected by the council from within its members to serve terms of two years. As of 2020
column2: Iowa City Council members are:

column1: Janice Weiner (At-Large)Under this form of council-manager government the powers of the city are vested in the city council. The council is responsible for appointing the city manager (as of 2016 Geoff Fruin) who implements the policy decisions of the city council
column2: enforces city ordinances and appoints city officials. The council also appoints the city attorney and city clerk.Iowa City is unusual in that it is one of only four cities in Iowa in which the mayor is chosen by the city council. The mayor of Iowa City serves a two-year term and has a vote on council
column3: representing the district or at-large position from which he or she was elected. The mayor is primarily a figurehead or a "first among equals"
column4: with some power to set agendas and lead meetings
column5: as well as serving as the public face of city government.

column28: publishes Monday through Friday while classes are in session. In addition
column29: The Gazette of Cedar Rapids maintains a news bureau in Iowa City.

column1: Little Village is an independent alt-weekly magazine covering Iowa City and Cedar Rapids metropolitan areas.
Iowa City has a general aviation airport
column2: the Iowa City Municipal Airport
column3: on the south side of the city. The Eastern Iowa Airport
column4: 20 miles (32 km) to the northwest
column5: serves Iowa City and Cedar Rapids with scheduled passenger flights.

column1: Interstate 80 runs east–west along the north edge of Iowa City. U.S. Highway 218 and Iowa Highway 27 (the Avenue of the Saints) are co-signed along a freeway bypassing Iowa City to the west. U.S. Highway 6 and Iowa Highway 1 also run through Iowa City.
Iowa City is served by the freight-only Iowa Interstate Railroad and the Cedar Rapids and Iowa City Railway (CRANDIC). The historic Iowa City Depot
column2: shown in the picture at left
column3: is no longer in use for railway services; it has been modified into a commercial office building.

column2: the Iowa City metropolitan statistical area (MSA) ranked as the seventh highest (tied with Hinesville-Fort Stewart
column3: Georgia MSA) in the United States for percentage of commuters who walked to work (8.2 percent). In 2013
column4: the Iowa City MSA ranked as the sixth lowest in the United States for percentage of workers who commuted by private automobile (73.4 percent). During the same year
column5: 11.1 percent of Iowa City area commuters walked to work.

column2: Coralville Transit
column3: and the University of Iowa's Cambus system provide public transportation.BONGO is a local app that tracks buses in real time. Their trip planner is still in beta.

column1: Intercity bus transit is served at either the Court Street Transportation Center in Iowa City or the Coralville Transit Intermodal Facility in Coralville.
There is a system of paved bicycle paths
column2: especially along the Iowa River.

column1: Some of the main roads also have designated bike lanes or sharrows
column2: such as Jefferson street
column3: Market street
column4: and College street. As of 2017
column5: both Iowa City and the University of Iowa have been awarded 'silver' status as a bicycle friendly community and university
column6: respectively
column7: by the League of American Bicyclists.
